metadata.title: Sonochemical synthesis of nanoplates of two Cd(II) based metal–organic frameworks and their applications as precursors for preparation of nano-materials

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ultrasonics Sonochemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/ locate/ul tson
Sonochemical synthesis of nanoplates of two Cd(II) based metal–organic frameworks and their applications as precursors for preparation of nano-materials
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ultsonch.2015.07.017 1350-4177/ 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: morsali_a@modares.ac.ir (A. Morsali).
Mohammad Yaser Masoomi, Ali Morsali ⇑ Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, Tarbiat Modares University, P.O. Box 14117-13116, Tehran, Islamic Republic of Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o a b s t r a c t
Article history: Received 5 May 2015 Received in revised form 27 June 2015 Accepted 20 July 2015 Available online 20 July 2015
Keywords: Ultrasound MOF Calcination CdO
Nano plates of two Cd(II)-based metal–organic frameworks, [Cd2(oba)2(4-bpdb)2]n (DMF)x(TMU-8) and [Cd(oba)(4,40-bipy)]n (DMF)y (TMU-9) were synthesized via sonochemical reaction by using various time and concentrations of initial reagents and power of irradiation and characterized by scanning electron microscopy, X-ray powder diffraction and IR spectroscopy. Moreover, the effect of triethylamine on speed of nucleation during the synthesis was investigated. Thermolysis of these MOFs at 550 C under air atmosphere yields CdO nanoparticles.
2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are known as porous materials which are extremely attractive because of their potential applications in gas storage and separation, ion exchange, sensing, catalysis, and drug delivery [1–10]. Designability is one of the unique features of these materials that can be manipulated by choosing appropriate organic ligands and inorganic secondary building units (SBUs) [11].
Synthesis of nanoscale MOFs has also been attractive [3,12,13]. Ultrasound irradiation is one of the simplest and most effective methods for preparation of nano or microstructures MOFs [14–17]. In this simple, fast and green method molecules undergo a chemical reaction because of powerful ultrasound radiation (20 KHz–10 MHz) [18]. Cavitation occurs during ultrasonic irradiation which involves formation, growth, and instantaneous implosive collapse of bubbles in a liquid, which generates local hot spots having temperatures up to 5000 C and pressures of 500 atm pressures with lifetimes of a few microseconds [19–21]. These extreme conditions induce chemical or physical changes
and can also enhance the formation of nano-sized structures, mostly via an increase of crystallization nuclei [22]. Ultrasound-assisted synthesis has been used extensively for preparation of MOFs and all the research indicates its usefulness for production of MOFs in nano and micro regions [23,24].
CdO, an n-type semiconductor with a narrow band gap (2.2 eV) [25]. It has been extensively studied for various applications, such as solar cells, optoelectronics, gas sensors and field-emission devices [26–29]. Up until now, various synthetic methods have been developed to produce cadmium oxide nanostructures [30,31]. Thermal decomposition of MOFs under various conditions has been widely studied with the aim to prepare metal oxide nanostructures with desire sizes and morphologies [32,33].
In this work, two Cd(II) based metal–organic frameworks based on a V-shaped flexible dicarboxylate ligand 4,40-oxybis(benzoic acid) (H2oba) and the N-donor ligands, 4-bpdb and 4,40-bipy, (4-bpdb = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene and 4,40-bipy = 4,40-bipyridine) have been synthesized via sonochemical method and the effect of ultrasonic irradiation time, power and concentration of initial reagents on shape and size of particles were investi-
gated. Also CdO nanoparticles have been obtained via calcination of these two MOFs at 550 C.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and physical techniques
sections.text:
All reagents for the synthesis and analysis were commercially available from Aldrich and Merck Company and used as received.
The ligand 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (4-bpdb) and was prepared by the reported method [34]. Crystals of two Cd(II) based MOFs, TMU-8 and TMU-9 were synthesized as it was reported in the previous paper [35].
Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus. IR spectra were recorded using Thermo Nicolet IR 100 FT-IR.
Ultrasonic generation was carried out in an ultrasonic bath SONICA-2200 EP (frequency of 40 KHz). The samples were
onventional heating or sonochemical reaction (samples A).
characterized with a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) ZEISS SIGMA VP (Germany) with gold coating.
The thermal behavior was measured with a PL-STA 1500 apparatus with the rate of 10 C min 1 in a static atmosphere of argon. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Philips X’pert diffractometer with monochromated Cu-Ka radiation.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Synthesis of TMU-8 and TMU-9 nanostructures
sections.text:
Ultrasonic syntheses of TMU-8 and TMU-9 were carried out in an ultrasonic bath at ambient temperature and atmospheric pressure for 30, 60 and 90 min (Tables 1 and 2). The resulting powder was isolated by centrifugation, washed with DMF three times and dried in air for characterization.
For nanoplates of TMU-8 (sample A): IR data (KBr pellet, m/cm 1): 516(m), 657(m), 687(m), 783(m), 825(w), 875(m), 1011(w), 1091(m), 1160(m), 1238(vs), 1305(w), 1396(vs-br), 1540(vs), 1599(vs), 1672(vs), 2927(w), 3060(w) and 3439(w-br) (Table 1).
For TMU-9 nanoplates (sample A): IR data (KBr pellet, m/cm 1): 501(s), 627(s), 656(m), 700(w), 785(s-br), 873(s), 1009(w), 1088(s), 1161(s), 1240(vs), 1398(vs-br), 1545(vs), 1599(vs), 1677(vs), 2929(w), 3058(w) and 3439(m-br) (Table 2).
For the study of the effect of concentration of the initial reagents on size and morphology of nano-structured TMU-8 and TMU-9, the above processes were performed with concentrations of [oba] = [Cd(OAc)2.4H2O] = [N-donor ligand] of [0.05], [0.025] and [0.0125] M. The effect of triethylamine (TEA) was investigated by adding 3 ml of TEA (in 20 ml DMF) to adjust pH to 7. Two different ultrasound powers (12 and 36W) were applied to achieve the best morphology of these two MOFs.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Two new three-dimensional porous Cd(II) based metal–organic frameworks, [Cd2(oba)2(4-bpdb)2]n 3.5(DMF) (TMU-8) and [Cd(oba)(4,40-bipy)]n (DMF) (TMU-9) have been readily and quickly synthesized by sonochemical process of a mixture of Cd(OAc)2 2H2O, H2oba, and 4-bpdb or 4,40-bipy. Comparison between the simulated (derived from the single crystal structures of TMU-8 and TMU-9) and experimental (resulting from the sonochemical synthesized powder) powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns confirm that nano plates of TMU-8 and TMU-9 were structurally identical to TMU-8 and TMU-9 prepared via conventional heating (Fig. 1) (as also evidenced by elemental analysis).
The IR spectra of sonochemically synthesized TMU-8 and TMU-9 are similar to those synthesized by conventional heating.
Both of them show the symmetric msym(COO) and asymmetric mas(COO) vibrations of the carboxylate groups at 1409 cm 1 and 1604 cm 1, respectively. Also the characteristic absorption peak (mC@O = 1679 cm-1) of DMF is present (Fig. 2).
In TMU-8 the oba ligands bind Cd2 units and form 2D sheets that are connected through the linear 4-bpdb, to form a three-dimensional framework. TMU-8 consists of two channels along the a-axis (aperture size: 9.3 3.9 Å and 6.7 3.0 Å, 44.3% void space per unit cell) [35] which are occupied by DMF guest molecules (Fig. 3). Also, TMU-9 contains narrow channels along a- and b-axes (aperture size 8.2 1.6 Å and 10.9 2.9 Å, respectively; 27.8% void space per unit cell) (Fig. 4) [35].
The morphology and size of TMU-8 and TMU-9 were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) by changing three parameters; sonication time, sonication power and concentration of starting materials as well as control of nucleation. Almost in all cases nanoplate was the dominant morphology.
For TMU-8, sonication time as a parameter was changed at a constant concentration of [0.025] M of starting materials.
Nanoplates of TMU-8 were obtained for all three sonication time (30, 60 and 90 min). For this MOF, thickness of plates is grown from 67 nm to 130 nm upon increasing the sonication time (Fig. 5). Therefore in sonication time of 30 min, concentration of initial reagents was changed to half and twice the first concentration ([0.0125] M, and [0.05] M). In this case thinner plates with thickness ranging from 25 to 60 nm were collected at lower concentrations (Fig. 6a and b). Also thinner plates (thickness of 80 nm) have been acquired upon using TEA in reaction with condition of 30 min and concentration of [0.025] M (Fig. 6c). This means in this case fast nucleation has the same effect as reduction of concentrations. Finally, in order to find out the effect of ultrasonic power on morphology and size of TMU-8, experimental condition of best sample (sample E) was set at ultrasonic power of 36W. In this case uniformly sheet-like morphology with thickness of 150–200 nm has been obtained (Fig. 6d).
A similar process was carried out for TMU-9 on same concentration of initial reagents. Results show that rod-shaped TMU-9 was obtained under these conditions in which the rods are made of
nano-sheets and the thickness of plates are reduced from 250 nm to 70 nm at longer sonication times (Fig. 7). Then in sonication time of 90 min, the role of concentration was investigated by choosing [0.05] M and [0.0125] M of initial reagents. For TMU-9, reduction of concentration leads to uniformly narrow nanoplates unlike those obtained upon using higher concentrations where non-uniform plates were acquired (Fig. 8a and b). Finally, the effect of using TEA on morphology and size of TMU-9 was investigated in
30 and 90 min of sonication times. The SEM images show the formation of separate nanoplates in which plates are more uniform in a shorter reaction times (Fig. 8c and d). In the case of TMU-9 increasing the ultrasonic power has led to nanoparticles ranging from 20 to 100 nm (Fig. 9).
To prepare cadmium oxide nanoparticles, these MOFs were calcined at 550 C for 2 h. Fig. 10 depicts the XRD patterns of the residue obtained from calcination of TMU-8 and TMU-9 nanoplates.
The Bragg diffraction peaks in the range of 2h = 20–80 exhibit the typical patterns of the cubic monteponite structure of CdO (JCPDS No. 05-0640, a = 4.69 Å).
SEM images of residue obtained from the direct calcination show the formation of aggregation of CdO nanoparticle in the range of 60–160 nm (Fig. 11). Particle sizes of CdO obtained from calcination of TMU-9 are smaller than those obtained from calcination of TMU-8. This may be related to the structures of these two MOFs that influence the final morphologies of CdO particles [32].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Nano plates of two porous Cd(II)-based metal–organic frameworks, [Cd2(oba)2(4-bpdb)2]n (DMF)x (TMU-8) and
[Cd(oba)(4,40-bipy)]n (DMF)y (TMU-9) were prepared by ultrasonic irradiation and various parameters such as time and concentration of initial reagents were investigated. Results show that lower concentration of reagents leads to decrease in particle size. Moreover, triethylamine influences the speed of nucleation during the synthesis and decreases particle size. Meanwhile, increasing power of ultrasonic irradiation led to uniformly sheet-like morphology for TMU-8 and nanoparticles ranging from 20 to 100 nm in the case of TMU-9. Finally, by thermolysis of these MOFs at 550 C under air atmosphere CdO nanoparticles were obtained.

sections.text: Support of this investigation by Tarbiat Modares University is gratefully acknowledged.
